descript.abstract: NAVIGABLE WATER, MINNESOTA represents navigable waterway centerlines within the state of Minnesota. It originated as an arc coverage with the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers. Then MnDOT extracted the arcs that lay within the state boundary. A description of the Navigable Water layer is included in Section 5 of this document - Entity and Attribute Overview.
descript.purpose: NAVIGABLE WATER, MINNESOTA was developed to fill a need at Minnesota Department of Transportation for a GIS layer of navigable waterways within the state for planning purposes.

timeperd.current: The original digitization was done during the 1990-1995 time period. For any given area, MnDOT used the most recent USGS 7.5-minute quadrangle available at that time. For BaseMap, the following data layer was updated as recently as January 2003 using the most up-to-date available information:

theme.themekey: transportation, inland, Waters, navigation, navigable water, River, and Routes

idinfo.accconst: The data may also be requested from the Contact Person listed below.

The disclaimer can be found in Section 6 of this document (Distribution Liability).
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 10.0

dataqual.logic: Data have been topologically structured and verified.
dataqual.complete: The layer is complete for the entire state of Minnesota.

horizpa.horizpar: Location accuracy for features derived from USGS 7.5-minute quadrangles cannot be assumed to exceed National Map Accuracy Standards for 1:24,000 scale maps (+/- 40 feet or 12 meters).

lineage.procstep: Lineage: During the time period 1990-1995, the BaseMap data layers were digitized from USGS 7.5-minute quadrangles using MicroStation CADD. A total of 1745 quadrangles were digitized. For any given area, MnDOT used the most recent quadrangle available at that time. The digital MicroStation CADD files were converted from State Plane Coordinates to UTM and then converted into ARC/INFO coverages. The ARC/INFO files were merged into statewide, seamless coverages and then attributes were added. The coverage has been updated continuously as information has come in. It originated as an arc coverage with the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers. Then MnDOT extracted the arcs that lay within the state boundary,and calibrated the layer.
